references.B87FRE01USGP: Fredrickson, L. H. and M. E. Heitmeyer. 1987. Waterfowl use of forested wetland of the southern United States: An overview. Pages 325-338 in Waterfowl in winter. (Weller, M. W., Ed.) Univ. Minnesota Press, Minneapolis.
references.B92AND01NAUS: Andrews, R., and R. Righter. 1992. Colorado birds:a reference to their distribution and habitat. Denver Museum Natural History xxxviii + 442 pp.
references.A90ZIC01NAUS: Zicus, M. C. 1990. Nesting biology of hooded mergansers using nest boxes. J. Wildl. Manage. 54:637-643.
references.R90BEA01USGP: Beall, J. T. 1990. Wood Duck nest box use in southern Puget Sound, Washington. Pages 259-263 in Proceedings of the 1988 North American Wood Duck Symposium. (Fredrickson, L. H., G. V. Burger, S. P. Havera, D. A. Graber, R. E. Kirby, and T. S. Taylor, Eds.) St. Louis, MO.
references.B96KAU01NCGP: Kaufman K. 1996. Lives of North American Birds. Boston, New York: Houghton Mifflin Company.
references.B83NAT01NAUS: National Geographic Society (NGS). 1983. Field guide to the birds of North America. National Geographic Society, Washington, D.C.
references.A88ZIC01USGP: Zicus, M. C. and S. K. Hennes. 1988. Cavity nesting waterfowl in Minnesota. Wildfowl 39:115-123.
references.B80POT01NAUS: Potter, E. F., J. F. Parnell, and R. P. Teulings. 1980. Birds of the Carolinas. Univ. North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill. 408 pp.
references.W09NAT01USGP: NatureServe. 2009. NatureServe Explorer: An online encyclopedia of life [web application]. Version 7.1. NatureServe, Arlington, Virginia. Available http://www.natureserve.org/explorer. (Accessed: March, 2010 ).
references.B88EHR01NAUS: Ehrlich, P.R., D.S. Dobkin, and D. Wheye. 1988. The birder's handbook:a field guide to the natural history of North American birds. Simon and Shuster, Inc., New York. xxx + 785 pp.
references.B76BEL01NAUS: Bellrose, F.C. 1976. Ducks, geese and swans of North America. Stackpole Books, Harrisburg, Pa.
references.A08SEN01USGP: Senechal, Helene, Gilles Gauthier, and Jean-Pierre L. Savard. 2008. Nesting Ecology of Common Goldeneyes and Hooded Mergansers in a Boreal River System. The Wilson Journal of Ornithology 120(4); 732-742
references.A84DOT01USGP: Doty, H. A., F. B. Lee, A. D. Kruse, J. W. Matthews, J. R. Foster, and P. M. Arnold. 1984. Wood Duck and Hooded Merganser nesting on Arrowwood NWR, North Dakota. J. Wildl. Manage. 48:577-580.
references.B83AOU01USGP: American Ornithologists' Union (AOU). 1983. Check-list of North American Birds, 6th edition. Allen Press, Inc., Lawrence, Kansas. 877 pp.
references.B93SIB01USGP: Sibley, D. 1993. The birds of Cape May. New Jersey Audubon Society, Cape May Point, NJ.
references.B88ALC01NAUS: Alcorn, J. R. 1988. The birds of Nevada. Fairview West Publishing, Fallon, NV.
references.B75HAR01HQUS: Harrison, H.H. 1975. A field guide to bird's nests in the U.S. east of the Mississippi River. Houghton Mifflin Company, Boston, Massachusetts. 257 p.
references.B93VEI01NAUS: Veit, R.R., and W.R. Petersen. 1993. Birds of Massachusetts. Massachusetts Audubon Society, Lincoln, Massachusetts. xv + 514 pp.
references.B80TER01NAUS: Terres, J.K. 1980. The Audubon Society encyclopedia of North American birds. Alfred A. Knopf, New York.
references.B80PET01NAUS: Peterson, R.T. 1980. A field guide to the birds east of the Rockies. Houghton Mifflin Company. 383 pp.
references.A69KIT01USGP: Kitchen, D.W. and G.S. Hunt. 1969. Brood habitat of the hooded merganser. J. Wildl. Manage. 33:605-609.
references.B76PAL02NAUS: Palmer, R. S., editor. 1976. Handbook of North American birds. Vol. 3. Waterfowl (concluded). Eiders, wood ducks, diving ducks, mergansers, stifftails. Yale Univ. Press, New Haven. 560 pp.
references.B80BEL01NAUS: Bellrose, F. C. 1980. Ducks, geese and swans of North America. Stackpole Books, Harrisburg, Pennsylvania. 540 pp.
references.B09DUG01USGP: Dugger, B. D., K. M. Dugger and L. H. Fredrickson. 2009. Hooded Merganser (Lophodytes cucullatus), The Birds of North America Online (A. Poole, Ed.). Ithaca: Cornell Lab of Ornithology; Retrieved from the Birds of North America Online: http://bna.birds.cornell.edu/bna/species/098.

habitat_description:
Northwest:
Require standing snag/hollow tree. Utilizes estuaries, marshes, swamps, lakes, and streams; winter habitat is mainly in freshwater but also regularly in estuaries and sheltered bays. Nests are typically found in tree cavities in forested regions near water, often fast-flowing streams, also forest lakes and ponds, flooded forest, riverside swamps. Will use nest boxes as documented by Zicus (1990). Will utilize spruce/fir forests in Washington (Beall 1990).

Southwest:
Nevada: uncommon winter visitant with possible nesting in western Nevada (Alcorn, 1988). Colorado: rare spring/fall migrant and winter resident in western valleys, mountain parks, & on eastern plains (Andrews and Righter, 1992). May be uncommon or common very locally. Casual in mountains outside parks. Very rare nonbreeding summer visitor in western valleys, mountain, mountain parks and on eastern plains. Habitat: reservoirs, ponds, and rivers. Easily disturbed, tends to avoid areas of human activity. Nonbreeding in 5 states. Possibly breeding in mountain regions in western United States, as far south as New Mexico. In winter, generally restricted to areas where average minimum January temperatures doesn’t drop much under -7 degrees C.  Migration habitat: open waters of rivers and lakes, brackish coastal bays, tidal creek, seasonally flooded forest, dead timber and shrub/scrub. Winter habitat: occupy shallow, freshwater, brackish bays, esturaries, and tidal creeks and ponds while they often concentrate along edge of ice. Generally found in river areas bounded by woods. New Mexico: migration and winter. Most common in middle and lower Rio Grande and lower Pecos valley. Occasionally in San Juan, Mibres, Gila valleys, Bitter Lake (BISON, 2000). In Arizona, occur on Apache-Sitgreaves, Coconino & Kaibab National Forests. Rare transients at Mormon Lake.

Southeast:
Hooded merganser's favorite winter habitats include forested freshwater wetlands, brackish estuaries, and tidal creeks. Occupy shallow, freshwater and brackish bays, estuaries, and tidal creeks and ponds, where they often concentrate along the edge of ice.  In Mississippi Alluvial Delta, they prefer deeper, more permanently flooded sloughs, backwaters, scrub/shrub, and overcup (Quercus spp), and oak/cypress/tupelo habitats (Fredrickson and Heitmeyer 1987). Habitat requirements in southern breeding areas are largely unquantified, although in Missouri nest boxes placed along slow moving, heavily forested rivers and lakes, and in dense buttonbush (Cephalanthus occidentalis)/cypress (Taxodium distichum) swamps seem to be preferred (quoted directly from Dugger et al. 2009).

Upper Midwest/Great Plains:
Closely tied to forested wetland systems throughout range, although nests in man-made boxes have been recorded in grassland areas in Minnesota (Zicus and Hennes 1988) and non-forested wetlands associated with riparian corridors (cottonwood/elder) in N. Dakota (Doty et al. 1984).
In Wisconsin (Kitchen and Hunt 1969), 75% of recorded broods occurred on a wide (20 m), shallow (33–66 cm), swift flowing (0.3 m/sec), forested river with 90% cobbled bottoms. Such habitat averaged 1.3 broods/km and contained the highest densities of fish and crayfish within the study area. Broods occurred on only 1 of 40 lakes sampled. Twenty-two of 30 observations of foraging broods were in waters over rocky substrate, which also supported the highest fish and invertebrate densities. Habitat requirements in southern breeding areas are largely unquantified, although in Missouri nest boxes placed along slow moving, heavily forested rivers and lakes, and in dense buttonbush (Cephalanthus occidentalis)/cypress (Taxodium distichum) swamps seem to be preferred (quoted directly from Dugger et al. 2009).

All Regions Winter:
Along both coasts, Hooded Mergansers occupy shallow, freshwater and brackish bays, estuaries, and tidal creeks and ponds, where they often concentrate along the edge of ice (e.g., Veit and Petersen 1993, Sibley 1993). Elsewhere found in a wide range of freshwater habitats including emergent marsh, small ponds, rivers, and creeks (quoted directly from Dugger et al. 2009).
